questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe low back pain radiating to the left leg. Physical examination reveals a positive straight-leg raising test at 20 degrees, and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot. Which is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRI scan

 

Explanation:

The presentation of severe low back pain radiating to the left leg, along with a positive straight-leg raising test, and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot is highly suggestive of disc prolapse, and MRI is the investigation of choice.

MRI provides clear visualisation of the prolapsed disc, nerve roots, and the thecal sac, helping to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of nerve root compression. MRI is non-invasive and offers superior soft tissue contrast compared to other imaging techniques, making it ideal for assessing spinal disc pathology.

 

Investigations of Disc Prolapse

Investigation

Details

Plain X-ray (Option B)

Useful to rule out bony pathology. In chronic cases, disc space narrowing and vertebral lipping may be seen.

Three types of osteophytes related to the degenerative spine: Traction osteophytes, Claw osteophytes, Wrap around bumper osteophytes.

Myelography (Option D)

Useful when CT or MRI is unavailable. Shows dye flow block, indentation, or root cut-off sign in lateral prolapse.

CT Scan

Reveals disc shape abnormalities, loss of pre-thecal fat, and herniated material pressing on nerve roots or theca.

MRI Scan

Gold standard. Clearly shows the prolapsed disc, nerve roots, and thecal sac.

Electromyography (EMG) (Option A)

Rarely required, but can localize nerve root denervation, especially in multiple disc prolapse cases.

 

Management of Disc Prolapse

Treatment

Details

Rest

Bed rest on a hard surface for 2-4 days.

Drugs

Analgesics and muscle relaxants for pain and muscle spasm relief.

Physiotherapy

Hot fomentation, gentle exercises, lumbar traction, and TENS.

Surgical Treatment

Indicated for cauda equina syndrome or failed conservative treatment.

Fenestration: Removal of the ligamentum flavum to expose the spinal canal.

Laminotomy: Creation of a small opening in the lamina for greater exposure.

Hemi-laminectomy: Removal of the entire lamina on one side.

Laminectomy: Removal of laminae on both sides along with the spinous process, often required for large central discs causing cauda equina syndrome.

Chemonucleolysis

Enzyme injection (chymopapain) into the disc to dissolve fibrous tissue.

Percutaneous Discectomy

Minimally invasive removal of the disc via endoscopic instruments or laser probes.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl comes to the orthopedics department with complaints of deformity of her back. On physical and radiological examination she has moderate curvature of the spine with a Cobb’s angle of 30 degrees. Which of the following is not an indication of surgery for scoliosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Postural curvature less than 30°

 

Explanation:

The clinical diagnosis here is scoliosis and for postural and structural curves that are of less than 30°, non-operative treatments are preferred and surgery is not indicated.

 

 

Tests for scoliosis:

  • Adam’s test:
    • A prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward.

Severity of scoliosis:

  • The severity of scoliosis is assessed by measuring the Cobb’s angle radiologically.

 

Cobb’s angle (degree)

Severity

0-10

Spinal curve

10-20

Mild scoliosis

20-40

Moderate scoliosis

>40

Severe scoliosis

 

Treatment of scoliosis:

Principles of treatment

  • The goal is to assess the prognosis of the curve based on:
    • Type of curve
    • Age at onset
    • Site of the curve
  • Prognosis:
    • Congenital curves progress faster than idiopathic curves.
    • Neurofibromatosis curves progress even more rapidly.
    • Younger patients typically have worse prognosis.
    • Thoracic curves lead to the most severe deformities.
    • Reisser’s sign shows no more progression of the curve.

Treatment guidelines:

  • Indications for surgical intervention:
    • Congenital scoliosis with signs of rapid curve progression, especially in the thoracic spine. (Option A)
    • Curves deteriorating radiologically may lead to significant deformity during pubertal growth spurts. (Option B)
    • Scoliosis is associated with back pain. (Option C)
  • Indications for non-operative treatment:
    • For postural curves and structural curves less than 30°.
    • Well-balanced double curves.

Non-operative methods:

  • Exercises: to strengthen spinal muscles and support the spine.
  • Braces:
    • Milwaukee brace: designed for effective support.
    • Boston brace: a more cosmetically acceptable brace.
    • Reisser's Turn-Buckle cast: body cast with a turn-buckle to stretch the concave side of the curve.
    • Localiser cast: body cast applied with the spine in traction, requiring a special localiser table.

 

 

 

 

Operative methods:

  • Spinal fusion:
    • Congenital scoliosis: simple fusion is usually sufficient.
    • Idiopathic scoliosis: achieve correction through pre-operative traction (Cotrel traction, localiser cast, halo-pelvic distraction) before fusion.
    • Per-operative correction is achieved using:
      • Harrington's distraction system
      • Dwyer's compression assembly
      • Luque-Hartshill systems

questions.text: A 30-year-old avid runner complains of a tender lump on the dorsum of his foot, just distal to the midshaft of the first metatarsal. He mentions that the pain started gradually after increasing his running distance. An X-ray image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) March fracture

 

Explanation:

A March fracture is a stress fracture commonly seen in runners, involving the metatarsals due to repetitive overuse. The patient's gradual onset of pain and tenderness after increased running and X-ray shows no obvious fracture, but a faint periosteal reaction matches this diagnosis.

Stress Injury (March Fracture):

  • Common in young adults, especially military recruits or runners; Caused by overuse, leading to foot pain and slight swelling.
  • Symptoms:
    • Tender lump, palpable just distal to the midshaft of the affected metatarsal.
    • Most commonly affects the second metatarsal, especially if it’s longer than the first.
  • Imaging:
    • Initial X-rays may appear normal.
    • A radioisotope scan shows intense activity in the affected bone.
    • A hairline crack may appear later (4–6 weeks), followed by callus formation.
  • In Older Adults:
    • Unexplained pain in elderly and osteoporotic patients may indicate a similar lesion.
    • X-ray diagnosis is challenging as it may show minimal callus or fine linear periosteal reaction.
    • Osteoporosis diagnosis via bone densitometry has to be considered.
  • Post-Surgery:
    • Metatarsal pain may occur after forefoot surgery due to stress fractures in adjacent metatarsals from redistributed stresses.
  • Management:
    • If there is no displacement, reduction or splintage is unnecessary.
    • Support the forefoot with an elastic bandage and encourage normal walking.


 

Jones Fracture (Option A): Involves the fifth metatarsal, usually caused by acute trauma, making it unlikely in this case of gradual onset pain in the first metatarsal.

 

Lisfranc Injury (Option C): A complex midfoot injury, typically from high-energy trauma, which wouldn't cause a localized lump at the first metatarsal.

 

Turf Toe (Option D): A sprain of the ligaments around the big toe joint due to hyperextension.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female dancer presents with pain and swelling in her right foot after landing awkwardly on the side of her foot while performing a dance move. She reports hearing a "pop" at the time of injury. Which of the following fractures is commonly seen in this scenario?

choices.text: Avulsion of the tuberosity of 5th metatarsal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Spiral fracture of distal 5th metatarsal

 

Explanation:

The mechanism of injury in this scenario points to the diagnosis of a dancer’s fracture, which is a long spiral fracture of the distal part of the 5th metatarsal after landing a jump.


 

  • The base, or the proximal aspect of the 5th metatarsal, is divided into 3 zones according to the Lawrence and Bottle classification.
    • Zone 1: the tuberosity
    • Zone 2: the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction
    • Zone 3: the diaphyseal area

Classification of fifth metatarsal fractures:

Type of Fracture

Mechanism

Location

Characteristics

Zone 1

Hindfoot inversion during plantarflexion (e.g., awkward landing)

Proximal to the 4th/5th intermetatarsal joints

Rarely involves the fifth tarsometatarsal joint; less severe

Pseudo-Jones Fracture (Tuberosity Avulsion) (Option A)

Zone 2

Significant adduction force to the foot with a lifted heel (e.g., sudden direction change)

4th/5th metatarsal articulation

15-30% nonunion rate; higher risk of complications

Jones Fracture (Metaphyseal-Diaphyseal Junction) (Option B)

Zone 3

Chronic repetitive microtrauma causing gradual onset of pain

Diaphysis of the 5th metatarsal

High risk of nonunion; increasing pain with activity

Diaphyseal Stress Fracture (Option D)




 

 

Jones Fracture

Pseudo Jones Fracture

 

  • Dancer's fracture:
    • Type: Long spiral, oblique fracture of the diaphysis of the fifth metatarsal.
    • Mechanism: typically occurs when rolling over the foot in a demi-pointe position or landing a jump.

 

Treatment and Management:

 

Fracture Type

Conservative Treatment

Surgical Treatment

Zone 1 (Pseudo-Jones fractures)
  • Protected weight-bearing with a hard-soled shoe or cast for 3-6 weeks.
  • Surgery if >30% of the articular surface is involved or >2 mm articular step-off (open reduction and internal fixation).

Zone 2

(Jones fractures)
  • Non-weight bearing in a short leg cast for 6-8 weeks.
  • Gradual weight-bearing as healing progresses.
  • Surgery for high-performance athletes, patients opting for surgery, or displaced fractures (intramedullary screw or tension band fixation).

Zone 3

(Stress fractures)
  • Non-weight bearing in a short leg cast, possibly up to 20 weeks.
  • Nonunion is common.
  • Surgery may involve intramedullary screw fixation or bone grafting, especially for high-performance athletes.

Dancer’s Fractures
  • Weight-bearing as tolerated, same as Zone 1 treatment for nondisplaced fractures.
  • Surgery for delayed union, nonunion, >3 mm displacement, or >10 degrees angulation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man suffered from an injury to his foot and has swelling and pain at the site. The X-ray image shows as follows:



Which of the following statements is true about the diagnosis?

choices.text: The Lisfranc joint is formed by the metatarsals and phalanges
Dislocations are common and can be caused by low-energy trauma

A subluxation or dislocation requires 4–6 weeks of cast or boot immobilization

A lateral view X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base
A lateral view X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A lateral view X-ray shows dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario and the X-ray image point to the diagnosis of a Lisfranc fracture, which on lateral view X-ray may show dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base.

 

Anatomy:

  • The Lisfranc joint is formed by the metatarsal bones (M1 to M5) and the tarsal bones (cuneiform C1 to C3 and cuboid). (Option A ruled out)
  • The Lisfranc ligament is a 3 part structure that joins the medial cuneiform to the 2nd metatarsal.
  • Interdigitating joints and strong ligaments support the five tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints.
  • The second metatarsal base fits into a recess formed by the medial, intermediate, and lateral cuneiforms.

 

Injury Mechanism:

  • Dislocations are rare and typically arise from twisting or crushing injuries, with the foot buckling at the midfoot–forefoot junction.
  • Often considered high-energy injuries, leading to extensive damage to the foot. (Option B ruled out)
  • The direction of forefoot dislocation is not useful for treatment guidance or outcome prediction.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Suspect TMT dislocation or fracture-dislocation in patients with foot pain and swelling after high-velocity impacts (e.g., car accidents, falls).
  • About 20–30% of these injuries are initially missed.
  • Obvious deformity usually only occurs with severe injuries.

 

Imaging:

X-rays:

  • Interpretation can be challenging; systematic examination is crucial.
  • Focus on the alignment of the second and fourth metatarsals (oblique view):
    • The medial edge of the second metatarsal should align with the medial edge of the second cuneiform.
    • The medial edge of the fourth metatarsal should align with the medial side of the cuboid.
  • A true lateral view may show dorsal displacement of the second metatarsal base.

 

Advanced Imaging:

  • If fracture-dislocation is suspected, stress views may help, but a CT scan is more effective for assessing the extent of injury.

 

Treatment:

  • Undisplaced Sprains:
    • Require 4–6 weeks of cast or boot immobilization.
  • Subluxation or Dislocation:
    • Accurate reduction is necessary, often achieved through traction and manipulation under anesthesia.
    • The position is stabilized with percutaneous K-wires or screws, followed by cast immobilization (non-weight-bearing for 6–8 weeks). (Option C ruled out)
  • Open Reduction:
    • If closed reduction fails, open reduction is essential.
    • Exposure of the second metatarsal base via a longitudinal incision for joint manipulation.
    • Fixation with K-wires or screws, followed by immobilization.

 

Complications:

  • Compartment Syndrome:
    • A tense, swollen foot may indicate serious compartment syndrome.
    • Measure intracompartmental pressures if suspected.
    • Prompt decompression through surgical incisions is critical; the wound is left open until swelling subsides.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with severe heel pain following a fall from a ladder. X-rays indicate a comminuted fracture of the calcaneus. Based on the expected changes in angles associated with this type of injury, which of the following is most likely?

choices.text: Reduced Bohler and increased Gissane angle
Both Bohler and Gissane angles reduced
Both Bohler and Gissane angles increased

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduced Bohler and increased Gissane angle

 

Explanation: Reduced Bohler angle (< 20॰) and increased Gissane angle (> 145॰) are indicative of a calcaneal fracture.

 

Calcaneal Fracture:

  • Most commonly occur during high-energy events leading to axial loading of the bone.
  • Falls from height and automobile accidents are the predominant mechanisms of injury.

  • Vital Angles in Calcaneal Fracture:

 

  1. Bohler’s Angle:
  • A line joining the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus and the highest point of the posterior articular facet.
  • Another line joining the highest point of the posterior articular facet with the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity.
  • Angle between the two lines is Bohler’s angle.
  • Normal value is between 25° and 40°.
  • Angles < 20 degrees: Calcaneus fracture.

 

 

 

  1. Gissane Angle:

  • A line drawn from the highest point of the posterior articular facet to the highest point of the posterior tuberosity.

  • Another line from the former to the highest point on the anterior articular facet.

  • Angle between the two lines is the Gissane angle.

  • Normal angle is usually between 120° and 145°.
  • An angle > 145 degrees: Calcaneus fracture.

 

  • Classification in Calcaneal Fracture:
    • Sanders classification: Requires the use of CT images
    • Essex-Lopresti classification: Based on conventional radiography
    • For accurate detection of calcaneal fracture, CT scan and 3D reconstruction is essential.
  • Treatment:
    • Undisplaced Fracture: Below knee plaster cast for 4 weeks followed by mobilization exercises.
    • Displaced Fracture: Open reduction and internal fixation.
  • Complication:
    • Early:
      • Swelling and blistering
      • Compartment syndrome
    • Late:
      • Malunion
      • Peroneal tendon impingement
      • Insufficiency of the tendo achilles
      • Talocalcaneal stiffness and osteoarthritis

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He reports severe ankle pain and is unable to bear weight. X-rays reveal a fracture in the neck of the talus, and is shown below. Based on Hawkin's classification, which type of fracture does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III

 

Explanation:

The X-ray indicates a displaced fracture of the neck of the talus, accompanied by dislocation of the body of the talus from both the ankle and subtalar joints, pointing towards a diagnosis of Hawkins Type III fracture.

Talus Fracture:

  • M/c Site: Talar Neck
  • Mechanism of Injury: Hyperdorsiflexion of the ankle

  • M/c Cause: RTA> Fall from heights
  • Also called aviator fracture:
    • When an aircraft strikes the ground at an angle, the foot rests on the rudder bar.
    • On impact, the talus is pressed into the instep, just in front of the heel.
    • Talus absorbs most of the force and becomes the site of the fracture.
  • Hawkin’s Classification:

 

Type I (Option A)

Undisplaced vertical fracture neck of talus

Type II (Option B)

Displaced fracture neck + Subluxation or dislocation of subtalar joint

Type III (Option C)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the body of the talus from both ankle and subtalar joints

Type IV (Option D)

Displaced fracture neck + Dislocation of the head and body of the talus from subtalar/ankle/talonavicular joints

 

 

  • Treatment:

 

Undisplaced Fracture

Displaced Fracture
  • Conservative treatment
  • Below-knee plaster cast
  • For 8-10 weeks
  • Closed reduction by traction in plantar flexion and a plaster cast is put in equinus.
  • If it fails, ORIF with lag screws is done.
  • Sometimes Herbert bone screw is used:
    • Headless compression screw
    • Generally not removed

 

  • Complication:
    • Avascular necrosis (AVN):
      • Hawkins I: 0% to 13% AVN
      • Hawkins II: 20% to 50% AVN
      • Hawkins III: 20% to 100% AVN
      • Hawkins IV: 70% to 100% AVN
    • Delayed union and nonunion
    • Malunion
    • Osteoarthritis of the ankle

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after falling from a ladder. He has tenderness over the heel and lower back pain. X-ray foot is taken and is shown below. What type of fracture might he have, especially given the association with lumbar spine injuries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lover’s Fracture

 

Explanation: Lover's Fracture involves the calcaneal fracture and is often associated with lumbar spine injuries due to the axial loading forces experienced during falls from height.

 

Lover’s Fracture: (Option A)

  • Type of calcaneal fracture.
  • Fracture of the calcaneal body and may be intra- or extra-articular.
  • A full spine evaluation is necessary for any calcaneal fracture, particularly after a fall, as the impact may also cause spinal compression fractures.

 

Maisonneuve Fracture: (Option D)

 

  • Fracture of the proximal 1/3rd of the fibula together with an unstable ankle injury, often comprising distal tibiofibular syndesmosis and deltoid ligament with or without fracture of the medial malleolus.
  • Mechanism: Pronation-external rotation injury.
  • Treatment:
    • Internal fixation of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis achieved by trans-syndesmotic screws.
    • Reduction and stabilization of medial malleolus fracture and/ ligamentous injuries.

 

Tibial Pilon Fracture: (Option C)

  • Also called Tibial Plafond Fractures
  • Caused due to high energy axial loading forces.
  • Involves distal tibia at its articulation with the talus.
  • Often associated with severe bone comminution and soft tissue compromise.
  • Treatment:
    • Minimally displaced fracture treated conservatively.
    • Grossly displaced fractures require surgical treatment consisting of open reduction and internal fixation with plate and screws.

 

Chopart’s Fracture: (Option B)

 

  • Occur at the midtarsal (chopart) joint, i.e. talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints.
  • Commonly fractured bones are the calcaneus, cuboid and navicular.
  • Occurs as a result of a high-energy impact, e.g. fall from height or road traffic collision.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic after twisting her ankle while stepping off a curb. She experiences significant pain and swelling around her ankle. X-ray AP view of the ankle joint is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cotton fracture

 

Explanation: The presence of fractures in the medial malleolus, lateral malleolus, and posterior malleolus indicates a Cotton fracture, which is a trimalleolar fracture.

 

 

Pott’s Fracture

(Option B)

Cotton Fracture

(Option A)

Description

  • Bony injuries and fractures around the ankle joint are colloquially known as Pott's fractures.
  • Bimalleolar fracture, it involves lateral and medial malleolus.
  • Percival Pott (1768) described a fracture of fibula 2–3 inches above the distal tip with an associated rupture of the medial ligaments and lateral subluxation of talus and therefore bears his name.
  • Trimalleolar fracture, it involves medial, lateral, and posterior malleolus.
  • This is a difficult injury complex to treat.

Fracture

Mechanism of injury:
  • Supination-Adduction injury
  • Pronation-Abduction injury
  • Supination-External rotation injury
  • Pronation-External rotation injury

X-Ray

Treatment

  1. Fracture without displacement: Below-knee plaster for 3-6 weeks
  2. Fracture with displacement:
  • Open reduction is indicated for failed closed reduction, displaced and unstable fractures.
  • Medial Malleolus Fracture:
    • Transverse fracture: Compression screw, tension-band wiring
    • Oblique fracture: Compression screws
    • Avulsion fracture tension: Band wiring
  • Lateral Malleolus Fracture:
    • Transverse fracture: Tension-band wiring
    • Spiral fracture: Compression screws
    • Comminuted fracture: Buttress plating
    • Fracture of the lower third of fibula-4-hole plate
  • Often requires open reduction and internal fixation.
  • Medial Malleolus Fracture:
    • Transverse fracture: Compression screw, tension-band wiring
    • Oblique fracture: Compression screws
    • Avulsion fracture tension: Band wiring
  • Lateral Malleolus Fracture:
    • Transverse fracture: Tension-band wiring
    • Spiral fracture: Compression screws
    • Comminuted fracture: Buttress plating
    • Fracture of the lower third of fibula-4-hole plate
  • Posterior Malleolus Fracture:
    • Involving <⅓ of the articulating surface of the tibia: No additional treatment
    • Involving >⅓ of the articulating surface of the tibia: Internal fixation with compression screws
    • Tibio-fibular syndesmosis disruption: Needs to be stabilized by inserting a long screw from the fibula into the tibia

After Surgery X-Ray


 

Lisfranc Fracture (Option C) involves disruption of the Lisfranc joint between the metatarsals and tarsal bones, characterized by specific radiographic findings such as misalignment of the metatarsals and the presence of the fleck sign, which are not indicated in this patient's X-ray results.

 

Chopart Fracture (Option D) occurs at the midtarsal joint (talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints), separating the hindfoot from the midfoot. The described injury involves fractures of the medial and lateral malleoli and the posterior malleolus, which do not relate to the midtarsal joint.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male sustained a high-energy impact injury to his left leg in a motor vehicle accident. He presents with knee pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. X-ray reveals a displaced lateral tibial condyle fracture. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Non-weight bearing with a knee brace
Immediate open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)

 

Explanation:

ORIF is the standard treatment for displaced tibial condyle fractures, especially in cases where there is joint instability or significant misalignment. Early fixation helps restore joint congruency and prevent long-term complications such as arthritis.

 

Complications
  • Compartment syndrome: Can occur due to increased pressure in the leg compartments, requiring emergency treatment.
  • Popliteal artery injury: Risk due to proximity of the tibial plateau to vascular structures.
  • Peroneal nerve injury: May result in foot drop due to nerve damage.

Management
  • Non-surgical: Stable fractures, minimal displacement (elderly).
  • Surgical (ORIF): Displaced fractures, significant depression, or bicondylar involvement (young adults).
 
  • Ligament reconstruction if needed.

 

Non-weight bearing with a knee brace (Option A): While immobilization may be part of the management, this is typically reserved for non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures. High-energy displaced fractures often require more definitive treatment.

 

Closed reduction and casting (Option C): Casting alone is typically not sufficient for displaced fractures of the tibial condyle, as these fractures often involve joint surfaces that need anatomical restoration, which is best achieved through ORIF.

 

Arthroscopic repair of meniscal tear (Option D): While meniscal tears may accompany tibial condyle fractures, the primary focus should be on addressing the fracture itself first. Arthroscopic interventions may be considered after fracture stabilization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old pedestrian after being hit by a car while crossing the street. The car's bumper struck his leg from the side, impacting the knee area. On examination, there is swelling, bruising, and a noticeable valgus deformity of the knee. The patient complains of difficulty walking and inability to bear weight. What is the most likely fracture sustained by the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral tibial condyle fracture

 

Explanation:

A lateral tibial condyle fracture is a common injury resulting from a valgus stress to the knee, especially in pedestrian accidents involving a lateral impact from a car bumper. Hence, it is also called Bumper fracture. The valgus deformity and difficulty bearing weight strongly indicate this fracture.

 

Classification of Tibial Plateau Fracture

 

The tibial plateau refers to the proximal tibial surface, which comprises the medial and lateral articular surfaces of the respective tibial condyles.

Lateral tibial plateau fractures are the most common.

Mechanism of Injury
  • The main mechanism of injury is a varus or valgus force, with or without axial load.
  • Young Adults: Road traffic accidents, leading to split fractures (high ligament injury risk).
  • Elderly: Trivial falls, causing depression or split depression fractures (associated with osteoporosis) (low ligament injury risk).

Classification (Schatzker)

Type I: Lateral plateau split fracture (young adults).

Type II: Lateral plateau split depression (young adults).

Type III: Lateral plateau pure depression (elderly).

Type IV: Medial plateau fracture.

Type V: Bicondylar fracture.

Type VI: Dissociation of metaphysis and diaphysis.

Clinical Features
  • Knee swelling due to hemarthrosis.
  • Inability to bear weight
  • Reduce range of knee movements
  • Compartment syndrome (earliest sign: stretch pain).

Imaging
  • X-ray: Initial fracture detection.
  • CT with 3D Reconstruction: Gold standard.
  • MRI: To assess ligament injuries.

Management

Non-surgical: Stable fractures with minimal displacement.

Surgical (ORIF): For displaced fractures or significant depression.

Ligament reconstruction if needed.

 

Medial tibial condyle fracture (Option A): This type of fracture is more commonly caused by varus forces or injuries to the inner side of the knee, typically involving lower-energy mechanisms, making it less likely in this scenario with a lateral impact.

 

Fibular head fracture (Option C): Although fibular head fractures can occur with lateral knee trauma, they typically result from rotational forces or direct impact to the fibula itself, not from valgus knee deformity patterns as seen here.

 

Patellar fracture (Option D): This injury generally occurs from direct trauma to the front of the knee or from a fall, and while possible in road traffic accidents, it is less likely in this case where the deformity and mechanism suggest lateral tibial condyle involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the function of the structure marked “B” in the below image?

choices.text: Anchors the intervertebral disc to adjacent vertebrae.
Distributes hydraulic pressure across the disc and absorbs shock.
Helps in providing nutrition to the surrounding annulus fibrosus.
Primarily resists torsion and extension forces on the spine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Distributes hydraulic pressure across the disc and absorbs shock.

 

Explanation:

Nucleus Pulposus is the gel-like core of the disc, composed primarily of water and proteoglycans, distributing hydraulic pressure across the disc and absorbing shock during spinal movements.

Intervertebral discs link vertebral bodies from C2 to S1, creating 23 discs (Cervical: 6, Thoracic: 12, Lumbar: 5) that makeup approximately 25% of the spine's height, which diminishes with age due to disc shrinkage. These discs grant flexibility and strength to the spine, acting as shock absorbers while preventing vertebrae from rubbing against one another.

  • The most common site of disc herniation is at L5-S1, which may be due to the thinning of the posterior longitudinal ligament towards its caudal end.
  • The thickness of intervertebral discs increases from the cervical to lumbar regions, except at the T3-T4 level, where it is slightly reduced. The relative thickness of the discs in the cervical and lumbar regions correlates with the spine's greater range of motion in these areas.
  • The discs in the cervical and lumbar regions are thicker anteriorly, contributing to the natural lordotic curvatures of these parts of the spine.
     

 

Components of Intervertebral Discs

Component

Description

Function

Nucleus Pulposus

Gel-like center with high water content, collagen, and proteoglycans

Mostly consists of Type II collagen

Distributes pressure, provides flexibility and shock absorption

Annulus Fibrosus

Consists of 15 to 25 concentric lamellae, of predominantly collagen, with interspersed proteoglycans, glycoproteins and elastic fibers

Mostly consists of Type I collagen

Encases Nucleus pulposus, provides strength, and resists compression and torsion (Option D)

Cartilaginous Endplates

Thin layers connecting discs to vertebrae

Maintains disc stability, allows diffusion of nutrients, anchor the discs to adjacent vertebrae (Option A)

 

 

Ligaments of the Vertebral Column

Anterior Longitudinal Ligament: Lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and discs, preventing anterior disc herniation.

Posterior Longitudinal Ligament: Lies within the vertebral canal and prevents direct posterior herniation of the Nucleus pulposus. Rich in nociceptive fibres, it is responsible for pain associated with disc herniation.

 

Blood Supply:

Most of the disc is avascular, except for the outer Annulus fibrosus. Blood vessels from the vertebral bodies and outer Annulus fibrosus supply nutrients to the Nucleus pulposus and inner Annulus fibrosus (Option C). Diffusion of glucose and oxygen nourishes these regions, and metabolites are removed similarly.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the types of scoliosis?

choices.text: Idiopathic scoliosis is seen most commonly in adolescents
Congenital scoliosis can grow rapidly and cause neurological deficits
Sciatic scoliosis is due to unilateral muscle spasms
The defect in compensatory scoliosis disappears when the patient bends forward

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The defect in compensatory scoliosis disappears when the patient bends forward

 

Explanation:

Compensatory scoliosis is formed to compensate for a pelvic tilt and the defect disappears when the patient sits and not on bending forward as in postural scoliosis.

Definition:

  • Scoliosis is a sideways curvature of the spine.

Pathology:

  • Primary Curve: lateral curvature of the spine.
  • Compensatory Curves: curvatures that develop in the opposite direction to maintain balance.
  • Vertebral Rotation: associated with rib prominence (rib hump) on the convex side, particularly in thoracic scoliosis.
  • Affected Areas: any part of the thoracolumbar spine; common patterns include:
    • Dorsal scoliosis
    • Dorso-lumbar scoliosis
    • Lumbar scoliosis


 

Non-structural (transient)

Structural (permanent)

  • Temporary curvature that can be corrected.
     
  • Postural scoliosis:
    • M/c type; Often seen in adolescent girls.
    • Mild leftward convex curve that straightens when bending forward.
       
  • Compensatory scoliosis:
    • Develops to compensate for pelvic tilt (e.g., due to hip disease or a short leg).
    • The curve disappears when the patient sits or when the underlying issue is resolved. (Option D)
       
  • Sciatic scoliosis:
    • Results from unilateral muscle spasms, often due to a prolapsed intervertebral disc. (Option C ruled out)
  • Involves permanent deformity.
     
  • Idiopathic scoliosis:
    • M/c structural type, can begin in infancy, childhood, or adolescence.
    • M/c in adolescents (Option A ruled out)
    • Infantile scoliosis may resolve or progress, while later-onset scoliosis can lead to significant deformity, especially in the thoracic region.
       
  • Congenital scoliosis:
    • Always associated with vertebral anomalies (e.g., hemivertebrae, block vertebrae, unsegmented bars).
    • These curves can grow rapidly and may lead to neurological deficits. (Option B ruled out)
       
  • Paralytic scoliosis:
    • Caused by unbalanced paralysis of trunk muscles, commonly due to poliomyelitis, cerebral palsy, or muscular dystrophies.
       
  • Other pathologies: Conditions like neurofibromatosis can cause structural scoliosis with associated kyphosis.


 

Radiological Features:

  • X-ray assessment:
    • Full anteroposterior (AP) and lateral X-rays in supine and erect positions are essential for evaluation.
    • Cobb's Angle: Measures curve severity based on the angle formed between the lines passing through the margins of the vertebrae at the curve's ends.
  • Risser's sign:
    It is a classification system that assesses the ossification of the iliac epiphysis, indicating skeletal maturity and growth potential. The ossification begins at ASIS and progresses posteriorly towards the posterior iliac spine. The classification consists of five stages:

 

Risser’s classification

Grade

Ossification of

I

Lateral 25%

II

Lateral 50%

III

Lateral 75%

IV

Lateral 100%

V

Fusion of the ilium
  • Risser stage 4 indicates cessation of spinal growth, while stage 5 correlates with the end of height increase.
  • This classification is crucial for predicting scoliosis progression, as completed growth suggests a reduced risk of curve worsening.

  • Vertebral rotation:
    • Observed through the position of spinous processes and pedicles on AP view.
    • Normally, the spinous process is centered but rotation causes it to shift to one side, resulting in asymmetry in pedicle positions.
  • Indicators of congenital scoliosis: Possible findings include wedging, hemivertebrae, unsegmented bone bars, and fused ribs.
  • Neurofibromatosis: Due to associated neurofibromas, it may show vertebral body erosion and widened intervertebral foramina.

questions.text: What result from the Modified Schober test would be considered positive for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis?

choices.text: Increase in lumbar flexion of less than 5 cm
Increase in lumbar flexion of 5-7 cm
Increase in lumbar flexion of 7-10 cm
Increase in lumbar flexion of more than 10 cm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in lumbar flexion of less than 5 cm

 

Explanation:
The Modified Schober test assesses lumbar spine mobility. In a positive test for ankylosing spondylitis, the lumbar spine shows a limited range of motion, with an increase in lumbar flexion of less than 5 cm. Normal results typically show an increase of more than 5 cm. Hence, an increase of 5 cm or greater is not suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Procedure:

 

Starting Position

Patient stands erect, feet shoulder-width apart.

Mark 1

Mark made at the lumbosacral junction (PSIS, approx. at L5).

Mark 2

Mark made 10 cm above the lumbosacral junction.

Mark 3

Mark made 5 cm below the lumbosacral junction.

Movement

Patient bends forward (without bending knees).

Measurement

Distance between marks is measured in full flexion.

 

Result:

 

Normal Result

Increase in distance by at least 5 cm (total distance ≥ 20 cm).

Abnormal Result

Less than 5 cm increase in distance, indicating reduced lumbar flexibility (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis).

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with chronic back pain and stiffness, primarily noted during the morning, which tends to improve with physical activity. X-ray imaging reveals characteristic findings given below. On ophthalmologic examination, what is the most likely ocular finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior uveitis

 

Explanation:

In a 28-year-old male with ankylosing spondylitis, X-ray findings typically include squaring of the vertebrae due to vertebral fusion and the dagger sign, representing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament. Anterior uveitis (iritis) is a common ocular complication linked to the inflammatory processes of this condition.

 

Anterior uveitis is the most common ocular manifestation in ankylosing spondylitis, seen in up to 40% of patients. It presents with pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease

Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)
 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)
 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
 
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae
 
  • Bamboo spine
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign
 
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)
 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test
 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance
 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)
 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

 

Keratoconjunctivitis(Option A): This is inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva, commonly associated with conditions like dry eyes or Sjögren's syndrome.

 

Episcleritis (Option B): Inflammation of the episcleral tissue is usually associated with other systemic diseases, like inflammatory bowel disease or rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Retinal detachment (Option D): This is a rare and unrelated condition to ankylosing spondylitis, typically occurring due to trauma or retinal conditions like diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the orthopedics department with complaints of lower back pain, heaviness, numbness, and paraesthesia in her thighs and legs which are relieved by sitting and squatting. She is diagnosed with lumbar canal stenosis. Which of the following is not a true statement about this condition?

choices.text: Congenital causes like achondroplasia can lead to lumbar canal stenosis
Central stenosis involves the area between facet joints carrying dural sac and nerve roots
This condition commonly affects women and degeneration is the most common cause
Undercutting facetectomies and ligamentum flavum removal is done for central stenosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Undercutting facetectomies and ligamentum flavum removal is done for central stenosis

 

Explanation:

Undercutting facetectomies and ligamentum flavum removal is done for lateral recess stenosis and laminectomy is done for central canal stenosis.

 

Spinal canal stenosis refers to reduced dimensions of the spinal canal that lead to neural compression.


 

Lumbar Canal Stenosis

Causes
  • Congenital: Vertebral dysplasia (e.g., achondroplasia, hypochondroplasia). (Option A)
  • Acquired:
    • Degeneration (most common) (Option C)
    • Spondylolysis
    • Spondylolisthesis
    • Iatrogenic factors
    • Post-traumatic
    • Local infection
    • Metabolic conditions

Anatomical Categories
  • Central Stenosis: Involves the area between facet joints; contains dural sac and nerve roots. (Option B)
  • Lateral Stenosis: defined by the lateral border of the dura to the medial border of the pedicle; Contains traversing nerve roots.
  • Foraminal Stenosis: located under the pars; contains exiting nerve roots.
  • Extraforaminal Region: lateral to the pars; may be compressed by far lateral disc protrusions.

Symptoms
  • Commonly affects women. (Option C)
  • Complaints include aching, heaviness, numbness, and paresthesia in thighs and legs.
  • Pain occurs after standing or walking for 5–10 minutes; relieved by sitting, squatting, or leaning (spinal claudication).
  • Patients may prefer walking uphill for symptom relief.
  • Unilateral symptoms may indicate foraminal stenosis.

Examination
  • Symptoms may be reproduced through walking, and neurological deficits are rare but possible.
  • Intact pedal pulses and the absence of trophic skin changes help distinguish from vascular claudication.
  • Differential diagnosis: Vascular claudication, hip joint pathology, and peripheral neuropathy have to be excluded

Imaging
  • In absolute stenosis, the mid-sagittal canal diameter is < 10 mm.
  • In relative stenosis, mid-sagittal canal diameter is between 10–13 mm.
  • MRI: Preferred
  • CT myelography: Indicated if MRI is contraindicated and is useful for dynamic stenosis.

Treatment
  • Conservative management:
    • First-line treatment for mild symptoms includes patient education, analgesics (e.g., paracetamol, NSAIDs), non-impact exercise, and epidural steroid injections.
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Is indicated for severe symptoms or failure of conservative treatment.
    • A posterior decompression needs to be done by methods like:
      • Laminectomy for central stenosis.
      • Undercutting facetectomies and ligamentum flavum removal for lateral recess stenosis.
    • Care is taken to preserve facet joints to prevent instability.
    • A spinal fusion may be required for foraminal stenosis and cases involving spondylolysis, spondylolisthesis, scoliosis, and kyphosis.
    • The SPORT (Spine Patient Outcomes Research Trial) shows that surgery is a more cost-effective method than non-operative treatment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with complaints of low back pain and difficulty participating in sports. Examination reveals increased lumbar lordosis and a noticeable step at the L5-S1 level. Radiographs confirm the diagnosis. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?

choices.text: Physical therapy focused on extension exercises

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Observation and activity modification

 

Explanation:

Conservative management is preferred for pediatric spondylolisthesis. Observation and modifying activities allow for monitoring and potential stabilization as the child grows, particularly when there are no neurological deficits or severe symptoms.

 

Clinical Features of Different Types of Spondylolisthesis

 

Feature

Isthmic

Congenital

Degenerative

Symptoms
  • Asymptomatic or low back pain.
  • History of trauma in 50% of cases.
  • Common in both adults and children.
  • Pain in lower back, buttocks, legs, and toes.
  • Known as pseudospondylolisthesis.
  • Intermittent symptoms, especially in the elderly.
  • More common in women (5 times) and affects 4-10% of the population.
  • Pain in the back, buttock, or thigh.

Deformity
  • Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • Palpable step at L5–S1.(Step sign)
  • Short torso, protruding abdomen.
  • Transverse furrow at L5.
  • Vertical sacrum.
  • Flat buttocks and hamstring tightness.
  • Prominent L5 spinous process.
  • Scoliosis present in 13%.
  • Scoliosis and pelvic waddle.
  • Flat buttocks.
  • Stiffness of the spine; limited bending.
  • Stiffness of spine.

Neurological Issues
  • Rare involvement of L5 nerve root.
  • Involvement of L5 or S1 nerve root; L5 involvement is rare.
  • Neurological claudication.
  • Commonly affects L3–4.

 

X-ray Examination for Spondylolisthesis

Lateral View:

  • Shows anterior displacement of one vertebra over another.

Oblique View:

  • Reveals defects in the pars interarticularis.

 

Normal appearance

Spondylolysis

Spondylolisthesis

  • Resembles a Scottish dog

  • Collar Appearance: Indicates a defect in the isthmus (pars interarticularis)

  • Defect without vertebral displacement

  • Separated Head and Neck

  • Defect with vertebral displacement

 


 

Principles of Treatment

 

Conservative Management

  • Rest and external support for the affected area.

  • Flexion exercises to strengthen the back.

  • Recommendation to change to a less physically demanding job.

 

Surgical Management

Indications

  • Failure of conservative therapy
  • Signs of nerve root compression
  • Slippage greater than 30% even without pain
  • Persistent pain in the back, thigh, or sciatica

Surgical Methods:

  • Posterolateral Fusion: Preferred method; preserves soft tissue and has a high fusion rate.
  • Posterior Fusion: Risk of additional slip postoperatively; often combined with intertransverse fusion.
  • Laminectomy: Relieves neurological deficits; usually followed by posterolateral fusion.
  • Laminectomy and Intertransverse Fusion: Additional stabilization method.
  • Anterior Interbody Fusion: Used for subtotal spondylolisthesis; complex and with uncertain efficacy.

Methods of Fusion and Stabilization:

  • Autologous cancellous bone grafting combined with devices like Hartshill rectangle frame or Steffee plate and screws for stabilization.


Radiographs showing posterior spinal stablization by Steffee plate and screws

Spondyloptosis

  • It refers to grade V spondylolisthesis, where a vertebra has moved so far forward relative to the one below that their endplates no longer align.
  • This condition typically involves anterolisthesis of L5 over S1


 

Immediate surgical intervention (Option A): Reserved for severe cases with neurological compromise; not indicated here due to manageable symptoms.

 

Epidural steroid injections (Option C): Not commonly used in children and inappropriate for this age group, more suitable for adults with acute pain.

 

Physical therapy focused on extension exercises (Option D): While beneficial, focusing solely on extension may not be appropriate; flexion exercises are often favored. Structured therapy would be considered if symptoms persist.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male athlete presents with lower back pain radiating to the left leg, exacerbated by physical activity. On examination, there is tenderness over the lower lumbar spine. X-rays reveal a defect in the pars interarticularis and a forward displacement of the L5 vertebra. Which type of spondylolisthesis is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Isthmic

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's age, activity level, and the presence of a defect in the pars interarticularis, isthmic spondylolisthesis due to a fatigue fracture is the most likely diagnosis. Pars interarticularis is the part of the vertebra bridging the superior and inferior articular facets.

Spondylolisthesis

  • It refers to the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one beneath it
  • Commonly occurring at the L5-S1 and L4-L5 levels.
  • Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars without the vertebra slipping forward.

Classification

Dysplastic (Option A)

  • Least common type
  • Caused by congenital anomalies in the upper sacrum or L5 arch, facilitating the slip.

Isthmic (Option B)

  • The most common type
  • Involving a lesion in the pars interarticularis, which can be further divided into three subtypes:
  • Lytic: A fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
  • Intact but elongated: The pars interarticularis remains intact but is elongated.
  • Acute fracture: A recent fracture of the pars interarticularis. The defect causes the anterior half of the vertebra to slip forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.

Degenerative (Option C)

  • Results from long-term intersegmental instability, where the pars remains intact, but degenerative changes in the facet joints permit forward slipping.
  • Common in older adults, where instability in the posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis can lead to displacement, occasionally backwards (retrolisthesis).
  • Severe displacement and neurological issues are rare.

Traumatic (Option D)

This results from fractures in other parts of the bony structure rather than in the pars interarticularis.

Pathological

Caused by generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the vertebral articulations.


 

Meyer Ding's Classification


 

Grade

Percentage of Forward Displacement

G1

Up to 25%

G2

25% to 50%

G3

50% to 70%

G4

Greater than 75%

G5

>100% - Spondyloptosis

 

The percentage of displacement is determined by measuring the upper vertebra's shift relative to the lower vertebral body on a lateral plain X-ray of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with low back pain radiating to the buttocks, thigh, and calf, which worsens when lifting heavy objects. He experiences numbness over the lateral side of his foot. On examination, there is a weakness of the plantar flexors of the foot and a sluggish ankle jerk. Straight-leg raising is positive, causing pain at 25 degrees. Which nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) S1 root

 

Explanation:

S1 root involvement is suggested by the clinical features: weakness of the plantar-flexors of the foot, sensory loss over the lateral side of the foot, and a sluggish ankle jerk (S1, S2). The straight-leg raising test, positive at 25 degrees, indicates significant nerve root compression, often seen with S1 root involvement.

 

Level

Nerve Root Affected

Motor Weakness

Sensory Loss

Reflexes

L5–S1

S1 root

Weakness of plantar-flexors of the foot

Over the lateral side of the foot

Ankle jerk sluggish or absent

L4–L5

L5 root (Option C)

Weakness of Extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexors of the foot

Over the dorsum of the foot and lateral side of the leg

Ankle jerk normal

L3–L4

L4 root (Option B)

Weakness of extensors of the knee

Over the great toe and medial side of the leg

Knee jerk sluggish or absent

L1-L4

L2, L3, L4 roots (Option A)

Weakness of hip flexion and adduction, knee extension

Over the anterior thigh and sometimes medial lower leg

Decreased patellar reflex

 

 

Clinical Features of Disc Prolapse

Clinical Feature

Description

Age and Lifestyle

Typically affects adults aged 20-40, particularly those with a sedentary lifestyle.

Low Back Pain (LBP)
  • Most common symptom.Can be acute or chronic.
  • Acute LBP: Intense pain and muscle spasms.
  • Chronic LBP: Dull, worsened by exertion, relieved by rest.

Sciatica
  • Pain radiating down the leg.
  • S1 root compression causes pain to the postero-lateral calf and heel.
  • L5 root compression affects the anterolateral leg and ankle.

Neurological Symptoms

Paresthesia ("pins and needles"), numbness, muscle weakness. In severe cases, cauda equina syndrome can occur, leading to paralysis and incontinence.

Posture

The patient stands with a rigid lumbar spine, and the trunk tilted forward or sideways (Sciatic tilt).

Movement Limitation

Restricted forward bending due to severe paraspinal muscle spasm.

Tenderness

Diffuse tenderness in the lumbosacral region, with localized tenderness near spinous processes in some cases.

 

Diagnostic Tests for Disc Prolapse

Test

Description

Straight-leg Raising (SLR) Test

The leg is raised until pain is felt in the buttock, thigh, or calf. Pain typically occurs between 30-70 degrees. Indicates lumbosacral root tension or disc prolapse.

Lasègue's Test

Extension of the knee in a raised leg. Normally, the limb can be raised 80-90 degrees, but disc prolapse reduces this to under 30 degrees due to severe pain. Dorsiflexion of the foot worsens the pain.

Neurological Examination

Assesses motor weakness, sensory loss, or reflex loss corresponding to the affected nerve root. L5 root affects extensor hallucis longus, tested by dorsiflexion of the big toe. Sensory loss in the corresponding dermatome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with lower back pain radiating to his right leg. MRI reveals a disc prolapse at L4-L5. Which of the following is the correct sequence of changes leading to the prolapse?

choices.text: Fibrosis of the nucleus → Disc extrusion → Calcification of nucleus
Nucleus degeneration → Nucleus displacement → Fibrosis and calcification
Disc sequestration → Posterior longitudinal ligament thickening → Degeneration of nucleus
Disc extrusion → Nucleus degeneration → Compression of nerve roots

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nucleus degeneration → Nucleus displacement → Fibrosis and calcification

 

Explanation:

  • The process of disc prolapse follows a sequence where degeneration of the nucleus pulposus occurs first, leading to softening and fragmentation of the nucleus. (Option B, C and D ruled out)
  • This is followed by displacement of the nucleus, where it bulges or extrudes through the weakened annulus fibrosus.
  • The final stage involves fibrosis and calcification of the remaining nucleus material as part of the repair process.
  • The most common site of disc herniation is at L5-S1, which may be due to the thinning of the posterior longitudinal ligament towards its caudal end.
  • The most common site of prolapse is postero-lateral, typically affecting one side of the spinal canal. In some cases, a central or posterior-midline prolapse may occur.

 

Stages and Consequences of Disc Prolapse

 

 


 

 

Stage

Description

Nucleus Degeneration
  • Softening and fragmentation of the nucleus pulposus
  • Weakening and degeneration of the annulus fibrosus

Nucleus Displacement
  • Protrusion: Bulging of the nucleus through a weakened annulus fibrosus
  • Extrusion: Nucleus extrudes through annulus but retains contact with the disc
  • Sequestration: Nucleus separates from the disc and becomes a free fragment

Fibrosis and Repair
  • Nucleus pulposus and the extruded material undergoes fibrosis and calcification
  • New bone formation and spur development at ligament attachment sites, leading to spur formation

 

Secondary Changes Associated with Disc Prolapse

Secondary Changes

Details

Spinal Canal Changes
  • Compression of spinal theca and nerve roots (usually one, occasionally multiple roots)
  • The nerve root affected is usually the one exiting below the disc level.
  • Large prolapse may cause Cauda equina syndrome

Intervertebral Joint Changes
  • Loss of part of the nucleus pulposus leads to fibrosis, reducing the height of the disc.
  • Results in incongruence and degenerative arthritis of the facet joints.
